p: Passiflora caerulea L., better known as the ‘blue passion flower’ [ 14], belongs to the family Passifloraceae, which is composed of 18 genera and about 630 species [ 15]. Passiflora is a rich source of phenolic compounds, amino acid α-alanine and organic acids, including butyric, formic, oleic, linoleic, citric, malic, myristic, linolenic and palmitic acids [ 16]. Passiflora plants are used in traditional medicine in South America to treat various pathologies associated with the gastrointestinal tract [ 17, 18], and also in the Netherlands, Spain, Italy and Poland [ 19]. They exhibit various pharmacological properties and possess biologically active complex compounds [ 20].
